diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immune Deficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by low levels of serum immunoglobulins and increased susceptibility to infections. Patients may present with sinopulmonary infections, autoimmune manifestations, and, in some cases, gastrointestinal issues. Telangiectasias and dysmenorrhea can be related to associated autoimmune disorders.

diagnoses.name: Selective IgA Deficiency
diagnoses.description: The most common primary immunodeficiency characterized by an undetectable level of immunoglobulin A (IgA) in the blood and secretions but with normal levels of other immunoglobulins. Patients may present with sinutitis, and gastrointestinal and allergic disorders.

diagnoses.name: Hyper IgM Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder characterized by normal or elevated levels of immunoglobulin M (IgM) with absence or very low levels of immunoglobulins IgG, IgA, and IgE. Patients may experience frequent infections including sinutitis.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Polyendocrinopathy-Candidiasis-Ectodermal Dystrophy (APECED)
diagnoses.description: A rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the combination of chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis, hypoparathyroidism, and adrenal insufficiency. Migratory pruritus and telangiectasias could be related to skin manifestations.

diagnoses.name: IgG Subclass Deficiency
diagnoses.description: An immunodeficiency syndrome where there is a deficiency in one or more of the IgG subclasses, leading to an increased susceptibility to infections, including sinutitis. Patients can have variable presentations based on which subclass is deficient.

diagnoses.name: Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare X-linked recessive disease characterized by eczema, thrombocytopenia, immune deficiency, and blood-tinged diarrhea. It's associated with decreased levels of immunoglobulins.

diagnoses.name: Gastrointestinal and Liver involvement in Primary Immunodeficiency Diseases
diagnoses.description: Patients with primary immunodeficiency diseases often present with gastrointestinal symptoms including dysmenorrhea as well as liver anomalies. Decreased immunoglobulins and infections can be part of the presentation.

diagnoses.name: Ataxia Telangiectasia
diagnoses.description: A rare, neurodegenerative, inherited disease causing severe disability. Ataxia refers to poor coordination and telangiectasia to small dilated blood vessels, both of which are hallmark features of the condition. Immunodeficiency is also part of its presentation.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder that causes the immune system to malfunction, leading to an inability to effectively combat certain infections. Patients may present with recurrent respiratory infections including sinutitis.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare, genetic disorder caused by a deficiency in the C1 inhibitor protein, leading to sudden and severe swelling attacks. While not directly linked to decreased immunoglobulins, it's an important differential when considering systemic symptoms and skin manifestations like migratory pruritus.

diagnoses.rationale: Dry eyes can be a common symptom of Sjögren's syndrome along with other symptoms that might not be as clearly related. Although not directly explaining all symptoms, parts can fit into the broader systemic effects of autoimmune processes.

If delayed puberty is significant, primary amenorrhea might be considered, especially in females, possibly relating to hormonal imbalances that could indirectly be associated with conditions like endometriosis.
Symptoms like constipation and dry eyes can be associated with hypothyroidism. Delayed puberty can also be a symptom of hypothyroidism.

Connective tissue disorders such as Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome could potentially explain a wide array of symptoms due to its systemic nature, possibly including gastrointestinal symptoms (like constipation) and issues related to skin and connective tissue (potentially linking to otitis externa).
While not directly associated with all listed symptoms, PCOS can be related to delayed puberty and may have indirect relationships with conditions like endometriosis.
Constipation is a major symptom in certain types of IBS. While not directly explaining other symptoms, it is a common gastrointestinal diagnosis that could coexist with other conditions.
This rare syndrome can lead to multiple organ systems being affected by autoimmune processes, potentially explaining a constellation of symptoms like those presented.

Celiac disease primarily affects the digestive system but can have systemic symptoms including delayed puberty and possibly even impacts on hormonal conditions like endometriosis due to overall health deterioration.

This genetic condition affects females and can lead to delayed puberty among other symptoms. While not explaining all symptoms, its broad effects on development could indirectly impact various health areas.
A common diagnosis when other causes are ruled out, it explains the constipation but requires other symptoms to be examined separately or as part of a systemic issue.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)

diagnoses.description: Asthma is a condition in which your airways narrow and swell and may produce extra mucus. This can make breathing difficult and trigger coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath.
A chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs. Symptoms include breathing difficulty, cough, mucus (sputum) production, and wheezing.

An anxiety disorder characterized by recurrent, unwanted thoughts (obsessions) and/or repetitive behaviors (compulsions). Understanding its relationship with conditions like cough or wheezing might require further investigation into stress or anxiety triggered physiological responses.
A skin disease that causes red, itchy scaly patches, most commonly on the knees, elbows, trunk, and scalp. Psoriasis can be associated with tags and onychodystrophy.
An allergic response causing itchy, watery eyes, sneezing, and other similar symptoms. Can be associated with coughing and wheezing due to post-nasal drip.
A condition that makes your skin red and itchy. It's common in children but can occur at any age. Tags and onychodystrophy might be observed in severe cases due to repeated scratching or infection.
A long-term condition where stomach contents come back up into the esophagus resulting in symptoms like cough and wheezing.

Mental health disorders characterized by significant amounts of anxiety or fear. Anxiety may lead to symptoms like obsessive-compulsive behavior, and stress from these conditions can exacerbate physical symptoms like coughing and wheezing.
A red, itchy rash caused by direct contact with a substance or an allergic reaction to it. The condition may be related to tags (skin tags) in chronic cases or in response to irritation.

A chronic, progressive condition in which the heart muscle is unable to pump enough blood through to meet the body's needs for blood and oxygen. While not directly related to obsessive-compulsive behavior or onychodystrophy, heart failure can result in symptoms such as wheezing and coughing due to fluid accumulation in the lungs.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV/AIDS can lead to a weakened immune system, resulting in increased susceptibility to infections, lymphadenopathy, and can also impact mental health, causing depression.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Cushing's syndrome, resulting from prolonged exposure to high levels of cortisol, can cause symptoms like striae, depression, and an increased risk of infections.

diagnoses.name: Depression with Somatic Symptoms
diagnoses.description: Severe depression can manifest with somatic symptoms such as dysosmia (altered sense of smell), fatigue, and immune system dysregulation.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs but can spread and cause systemic symptoms such as lymphadenopathy and an increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, particularly the lungs and lymph glands, leading to lymphadenopathy and potentially impacting the immune system.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation and organ damage, including skin manifestations like striae, lymphadenopathy, and increased risk of infections.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis (Mono)
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, presenting with symptoms including lymphadenopathy, increased susceptibility to infections, and fatigue, which can contribute to feelings of depression.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: A tick-borne illness that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including lymphadenopathy, depression, and potentially altered sense of smell (dysosmia) in later stages.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder that occurs when the adrenal glands produce insufficient amounts of certain hormones, leading to symptoms including depression, susceptibility to infections, and possibly changes in skin pigmentation or striae.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that originates in the lymphatic system, causing lymphadenopathy, increased risk of infections due to immune system compromise, and can also affect emotional well-being, potentially leading to depression.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV/AIDS can lead to a weakened immune system, potentially causing symptoms such as lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes), anemia, cognitive issues such as word-finding difficulty, and hypersensitivity reactions. A chronic cough may also be present due to opportunistic infections.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy, cough, hypersensitivity reactions, and anemia. Neurosarcoidosis can lead to neurological problems, including word-finding difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: SLE is an autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation and organ damage. Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy, anemia, cognitive issues such as word-finding difficulties, and hypersensitivity reactions. A chronic cough may also be present if the lungs are involved.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Lymphoma is a type of cancer that originates in the lymphatic system, leading to lymphadenopathy. Anemia, cough (due to lymph node pressure or involvement of the lungs), and hypersensitivity reactions can also be symptoms of lymphoma. Some patients may experience cognitive difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: Tuberculosis is a bacterial infection that primarily affects the lungs but can also spread to lymph nodes, causing lymphadenopathy. It may lead to anemia, cough, and in some cases, hypersensitivity reactions such as erythema nodosum. Cognitive symptoms can occur, particularly in advanced stages.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Mononucleosis, usually caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, can result in symptoms such as lymphadenopathy, anemia from destruction of red cells, cough, and in rare cases, cognitive issues like word-finding difficulties, due to the general fatigue and malaise it causes.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder affecting joints but can have systemic effects, including lymphadenopathy, anemia, and hypersensitivity reactions. Lung involvement can lead to a chronic cough. Neurological manifestations can occasionally include cognitive difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A sexually transmitted infection that can cause a wide range of symptoms depending on the stage, including lymphadenopathy, anemia, neurological problems such as word-finding difficulties (in tertiary syphilis), and hypersensitivity reactions. A cough is less common but can occur.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by the body's inability to properly regulate the number of immune system cells (lymphocytes), leading to lymphadenopathy, anemia, and potentially cognitive issues due to the impact on overall health. Hypersensitivity reactions are also common.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: While primarily a lung disorder leading to chronic cough and respiratory symptoms, COPD can indirectly cause lymphadenopathy due to chronic inflammation, anemia of chronic disease, and in advanced stages, cognitive issues due to hypoxia. Hypersensitivity reactions can occur, often related to environmental or medication triggers.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. In people with sarcoidosis, abnormal masses or nodules consisting of inflamed tissues form in certain organs of the body.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of lymphoma, which is a cancer originating from lymphocytes, a type of white blood cells. Symptoms include the enlargement of lymph nodes, spleen, or other immune tissue.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A diverse group of blood cancers that include any kind of lymphoma except Hodgkin's lymphomas. Symptoms can include lymph node enlargement, fever, night sweats, weight loss, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect various parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, blood cells, brain, heart, and lungs. Symptoms vary but can include fatigue, joint pain, rash, and fever.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus/Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome is a spectrum of conditions caused by infection with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), which compromises the immune system.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder that affects the immune system, characterized by the body’s inability to effectively fight certain types of infections. It can cause granulomas, which are masses or nodules of inflammatory tissue.

diagnoses.name: Castleman Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder that involves an overgrowth of cells in the body’s lymph nodes and related tissues. It can cause symptoms similar to lymphoma including lymph node enlargement, fever, and weight loss.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. Symptoms can include sores in the mouth and on the genitals, severe tiredness, headache, and skin lesions.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), it's a disorder marked by inflammation of blood vessels. Symptoms include asthma, sinus changes, and neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Airway Disease Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A term often used to describe a history that suggests asthma but does not yet meet the full criteria for diagnosis. Symptoms can include wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
reasoning: Gastroparesis, irritability, hyperglycemia, and increased susceptibility to infection can all be complications or symptoms associated with poorly managed diabetes.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
reasoning: Hyperglycemia and irritability can be linked to hyperthyroidism, while increased susceptibility to infections can indicate an overall compromised health state often seen in thyroid disorders.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
reasoning: Hyperglycemia and increased susceptibility to infections are symptoms of Cushing's syndrome. Gastroparesis and irritability can also be indirect symptoms due to the overall body's response to excessive cortisol.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease
reasoning: Increased susceptibility to infections is a hallmark symptom of Chronic Granulomatous Disease, and though less common, other symptoms may indirectly affect glucose metabolism, leading to hyperglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Asthma or Allergic Rhinitis
reasoning: Congestion is a primary symptom of both asthma and allergic rhinitis. While not directly related, the stress from constant congestion and poor oxygenation could potentially exacerbate other conditions like irritability or hyperglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Cystic Fibrosis
reasoning: Cystic fibrosis can lead to gastroparesis due to thick mucus blocking the digestive tract, increased susceptibility to infections due to compromised lung function, and congestion is a common symptom. Diabetes, or CFRD (Cystic Fibrosis-Related Diabetes), is another complication, covering the symptom of hyperglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Immune Deficiency Disorders
reasoning: Increased susceptibility to infections is a direct symptom of immune deficiency disorders. Secondary symptoms might include complications that indirectly lead to gastroparesis, hyperglycemia through infection or medication, and irritability from the overall health impacts.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
reasoning: Hyperglycemia is not a typical feature of Addison's disease; however, irritability and susceptibility to infections can be symptoms due to the decrease in cortisol production. Congestion is not directly related but can be a symptom of concurrent autoimmune or infection processes.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
reasoning: While GERD mainly presents with heartburn and acid reflux, severe cases can affect gastric emptying, potentially leading to gastroparesis. Congestion can also be a symptom if reflux reaches the larynx or lungs.

diagnoses.name: Autonomic Neuropathy
reasoning: Autonomic neuropathy, especially in the context of diabetes, can lead to gastroparesis due to the nerves controlling the stomach's muscles being damaged. It can also affect blood sugar levels, leading to hyperglycemia.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
COVID-19 (considering recent pandemics and its known effects on smell)

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV/AIDS can lead to a weakened immune system, resulting in increased susceptibility to infections, lymphadenitis, and various skin conditions such as xerosis.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Lymphomas, including Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, can cause lymphadenitis (swollen lymph nodes), increased susceptibility to infections, and headaches due to pressure effects of swollen nodes or masses.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: SLE is an autoimmune disease that can present with lymphadenopathy, increased risk of infections, headaches, and xerosis due to its systemic involvement.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: Sarcoidosis often involves the lymphatic system, leading to lymphadenitis. It can also cause a wide array of other symptoms including skin dryness (xerosis) and neurological symptoms like headaches.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Chronic fatigue syndrome may exhibit a range of symptoms including headaches, lymphadenopathy, and an increased susceptibility to infections, although it is a diagnosis of exclusion.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome
diagnoses.description: This condition involves abnormal lymphocyte survival, leading to lymphadenopathy, increased risk of infections, and autoimmune manifestations, which might indirectly cause symptoms like headaches and skin dryness.

diagnoses.name: Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID)
diagnoses.description: SCID is a group of rare, sometimes fatal, congenital disorders that can cause an increased susceptibility to infections, lymphadenopathy, and can indirectly lead to symptoms like headaches and xerosis due to the body's weakened state.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: Tuberculosis can present with systemic symptoms like lymphadenitis, increased susceptibility to infections, and nonspecific symptoms like headaches. Skin manifestations can sometimes include xerosis.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: Syphilis, a sexually transmitted infection, can cause lymphadenopathy, headaches, and make an individual more susceptible to other infections. Skin changes, including xerosis, can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: These disorders present early in life with an increased susceptibility to infections, lymphadenopathy, and can be complex involving multiple organ systems, potentially leading to headaches and skin dryness.

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Chemical poisoning (e.g., from pesticides or toxic plants)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Toxic exposure (e.g., to chemicals or allergens)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Respiratory infections (such as the common cold or influenza)
Severe allergic reaction to food, insect stings, or drugs
Neurogenic shock due to spinal cord injury
Intoxication (e.g., carbon monoxide poisoning, heavy metal poisoning)

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by severe head pain followed or accompanied by sensory disturbances such as flashes of light, blind spots, tingling in the arms and legs, nausea, vomiting, and increased sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA presents with symptoms similar to a stroke but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage. It’s often a warning sign of a future stroke.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms depend on the area of the brain affected and can include headache, weakness, and problems with speech.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain or the skull vault. Symptoms can include headaches, seizures, weakness, aphasia, and vision problems.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms include weakness, numbness, and in some cases, speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive Encephalopathy
diagnoses.description: A syndrome that occurs in patients with severe hypertension, characterized by headache, confusion, seizures, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms can include headache, fever, stiffness of the neck, and sensitivity to light.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, often due to infection. Causes flu-like symptoms such as fever and headache, sometimes progressing to seizures or sensory disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Psychogenic Non-Epileptic Seizures (PNES)
diagnoses.description: Seizure-like episodes that aren't caused by electrical disruptions in the brain and are thought to have a psychological origin. Symptoms can mimic those of epilepsy but don't respond to standard epilepsy treatments.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, typically progressive disease involving damage to the sheaths of nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, symptoms may include numbness, impairment of speech and of muscular coordination, blurred vision and severe fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves neurological phenomena (aura) like visual disturbances (scintillation) and other sensory changes that precede the headache phase of the migraine.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms may include paralysis or weakness on one side of the body, difficulty understanding or speaking, dizziness, or loss of vision to one side.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a brief period of symptoms similar to those in a stroke, such as paralysis or weakness on one side of the body, which can include parasthesia, but typically lasts less than five hours without causing permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A result of damage to the nerves located outside of the brain and spinal cord (peripheral nerves), often causes weakness, numbness and pain, usually in your hands and feet, but it can also affect other areas and functions of your body, including digestion, urination, and circulation.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from a restricted blood supply to the back of the brain, caused by blockage or damage in the vertebral or basilar arteries. Symptoms can include dizziness, visual disturbances, weakness, and difficulty speaking or swallowing.

diagnoses.name: Acoustic Neuroma
diagnoses.description: A benign tumor on the main nerve leading from the inner ear to the brain. Pressure from the tumor can cause hearing loss, ringing in the ear (tinnitus), and a feeling of fullness in the ear, along with balance issues.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Lack of B12 can cause a wide range of symptoms including fatigue, weakness, numbness or tingling in the limbs, and issues with walking and balance.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder where the body's immune system attacks the nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Early symptoms may include fever, headache, fatigue, depression, and a characteristic skin rash called erythema migrans. If untreated, infection can spread to the joints, heart, and nervous system, causing more serious symptoms.

diagnoses: Viral Infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C)
Bullous pemphigoid with autoimmune hemolytic anemia
Drug-induced immune thrombocytopenia and hemolytic anemia

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: SLE can manifest with a wide range of symptoms including alopecia, thrombocytopenia, and pericarditis. Proteinuria indicates possible lupus nephritis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.reason: MCTD can present with features of several connective tissue diseases including lupus, with symptoms such as pericarditis, and may also show signs of skin involvement like telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.reason: Scleroderma can cause skin changes like telangiectasias and nonscarring alopecia, along with kidney involvement manifesting as proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.reason: Dermatomyositis presents with a characteristic rash which can include telangiectasias and symptoms of connective tissue disease such as pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: While primarily affecting connective tissues leading to joint hypermobility and skin elasticity, vascular types can manifest with telangiectasias. It’s less commonly associated with the other listed symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
diagnoses.reason: This form of vasculitis can cause kidney damage shown by proteinuria and may lead to skin manifestations although nonscarring alopecia and telangiectasias are less typical.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome)
diagnoses.reason: This genetic disorder is characterized by telangiectasias. It's less commonly associated with thrombocytopenia, alopecia, or proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura
diagnoses.reason: While primarily characterized by thrombocytopenia, it doesn't typically present with the full range of the given symptoms but can be considered in differential diagnosis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.reason: Some patients with severe RA can develop symptoms like pericarditis and have associated renal issues including proteinuria, although it's less commonly associated with skin manifestations such as telangiectasias or alopecia.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schonlein Purpura
diagnoses.reason: Predominantly seen in children, it presents with renal involvement (proteinuria), and can sometimes have systemic manifestations though telangiectasias and nonscarring alopecia are less common.

diagnoses: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) with secondary hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection with cryoglobulinemia
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Vasculitis (e.g., Polyarteritis Nodosa, Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
Hepatitis B or C associated vasculitis
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Churg-Strauss syndrome)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Stevens-Johnson Syndrome / Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (Overlapping spectrum)
